results.title: Beneath Roads
results.creator_credit: Jenna Warwick, Rah Dakota and Field Carr
results.credit_line:

Produced by the Country Roads Board, 1952
Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

The Back of Beyond
John Heyer, 1956
Courtesy the John Heyer Estate

Transport in Australia - “Roads at Work”
John Milson/The Commonwealth Film Unit, 1966
Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

Courtesy Bill Bennett, b:j Films

Beneath Clouds

results.material_description:
mutli-channel, colour, black and white, sound
9 min 7 sec
results.brief_description:
Beneath Roads is a response to a purposeful void in Australia’s collective knowledge. Long before horses and carts found their way across the country, the land was crisscrossed by Indigenous pathways that remain the foundation for countless highways and roadways today.

Knowledge of these routes, their features and cultural significance is depicted in songs, which are memorised and passed down through generations. These traditional forms of navigation and spiritual understanding of place are known as Songlines. Many of the roads you drive on today are the result of this practice. One of the most identifiable pathways in Victoria navigated for centuries is the Omeo highway connecting north-east Victoria to Gippsland through Ngarigo, Jaitmatang and Gunnai Kurnai Country.

This visual poem ruminates on the layering of bitumen over these ancient routes through the lens of Australian cinema. The portrayal of the outback on screen has become one of this nation’s most recognisable cultural exports and the road genre offers one way to unpack a constructed national identity.

ABOUT THE SOURCES

Beneath Roads is assembled from a range of different film sources.

Ivan Sen’s debut feature, the road film Beneath Clouds (2002), considers the unresolved tensions of settler Australia. As two Indigenous teenagers, Vaughn (Damien Pitt) and Lena (Dannielle Hall), hitchhike toward Sydney, their journey is defined more by racism than the freedom that the road often symbolises. Director of photography Allan Collins captures the landscape as one hemmed in by powerlines and overcast skies, the terrain patrolled by cops and trampled by industry. But despite these settler interventions, the beauty and grandeur of Country prospers, captured through wide vistas and intimate close-ups of the landscape. Both Sen and Collins won an AACTA award for Best Director and Best Cinematography respectively.

Beneath Clouds and other narrative titles are juxtaposed with archival historical films about Australian road building. These Government-made promotional films of the 1950s and 60s were used to build support for ‘nation building’ and were released during the same period First Peoples gained the right to vote in 1962. These are included in Beneath Roads to highlight the lack of awareness of centuries-old Indigenous navigation and travel routes upon which many modern roads were built.

Beneath Roads further counters this lack of awareness by including footage of the Southern Warriors, a Victorian Aboriginal motorcycle club. On Survival Day in 2024, the Southern Warriors rode to Coranderrk mission to honour Wurundjeri activist William Barak’s historic protest walks from Coranderrk to Melbourne, during which Barak advocated for the mission and his people’s rights. Historically First Peoples’ ability to travel was restricted by systemic racism and discriminatory government policies that pervaded Australia until the 1970s. The Southern Warriors stand in stark contrast to this history, representing a sense of freedom, safety and pride for Indigenous communities. Impossible to ignore, the self-described ‘warriors’ travel the state Black, loud and proud.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jenna Warwick, Rah Dakota and Field Carr

details.label: Materials

results.title: Delivery Dancer's Sphere: 0° Receiver
results.brief_description:
South Korean artist Ayoung Kim blends cinematic storytelling, videogame technology and science fiction in her mind-bending new work, Deliver Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver. Drawing on influences that range from Blade Runner (1992)’s techno-futurist cityscapes to an 18th-century Indian astronomical observatory, Kim twists sci-fi tropes into a speculative story rich with otherworldly doubles, interdimensional journeys and colliding worlds.

From a high-octane motorcycle chase through ancient ruins to a cat-and-mouse game down neon streets, an ordinary delivery driver must outrun her enemies and embrace her destiny to save time-keeping traditions across possible worlds. With a dynamic mix of live-action footage, app interfaces, CGI avatars and landscapes powered by game engines, Kim uses the tools of screen culture and our hyper-networked age to question time, productivity and the self.

Ayoung Kim’s deep research into geopolitics, mythology and technology forms the basis of her work. She establishes idiosyncratic connections between biopolitics and border control, the memory of stone and virtual memory, ancestral origins and imminent futures. These narratives take the forms of video, VR, sonic fiction, image, diagram and text, and are presented as exhibitions, performances, theatrical projects and publications.

Through the creation of engaging characters and stories, Kim explores her theoretical interest in the intersections of time, space and knowledge systems.

Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver continues the story of Ayoung Kim’s award-winning Delivery Dancer’s Sphere (2022). Made during the COVID-19 pandemic, the first work follows courier Ernst Mo and her doppelganger En Storm as they navigate a techno-futuristic Seoul under the eye of a tyrannical algorithm, expressed through a delivery app. Its mission is to control time through efficiency and productivity, reflecting how society pushes us towards self-optimisation and economic output.

In Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver, Ernst Mo and En Storm escape the endless maze of package pick-ups and deliveries. No longer ordinary couriers, they transport time itself across deserts, cities and different dimensions. Traversing different calendar mechanics and astronomical technologies, they’re tangled in networks of space and time that contradict and collide.

Through settings and dialogue, Kim evokes pre-colonial and non-Western knowledge systems, presenting an alternative to our increasingly fractured and accelerated life. By mixing ancient wisdom and navigation techniques with advanced technology and aesthetics, another possible world – and ways of moving through it – emerges.

How it was made

Ayoung Kim began by writing a detailed script, which ran over 60 pages. The work was shot using a combination of traditional filmmaking, CGI and videogame techniques.

Much of the footage was shot with actors on location, but the opening desert world, the kaleidoscopic zero-gravity space and other worlds were made in the videogame engine Unity. Kim also imported LiDAR scans of building interiors to Unity, allowing her to control camera angles in a way that wouldn’t otherwise be possible.

To create the animated avatars, Kim used motion capture footage of dancers and martial arts choreographers. The project required a skilled crew, including costume designers, 3D modellers, choreographers, CGI animators and sound designers.

Ideas of time and navigation

The artwork opens on the vernal equinox, a twice-annual period when the sun is exactly above the equator. It’s the only time global positioning systems (GPS), which track Ernst Mo and En Storm’s position and productivity, can be disrupted. This astrological event allows the duo to strike against the algorithm as part of a multiverse resistance.

The symmetrical stone structure seen at the beginning of the artwork is the Vrihat Samrat Yantra, an enormous sundial at the Jantar Mantar observatory in Jaipur, India. It represents an older way of keeping time, offering a counterpoint to digital interfaces like the Delivery Dancer app, which cheerfully gives Ernst Mo her delivery routes and directives.

When Ernst Mo and En Storm fall from the cliff, their own app and travel device, ‘Guest Stars’, activates. You can hear chant-like whispers counting time in different calendar systems, including Buddhist, Celtic, Persian, Hebrew, Hijri (Islamic), Shaka Samvat (Hindu), Jawa (Indonesian), Japanese, Lunar (Korean), Taiwanese and Gregorian calendars, as the characters are transported to other possible worlds. Guest Stars’ was inspired by an unofficial app developed by drivers on the Indonesian platform Gojek. It also references an era before GPS when people would use stars to navigate and the sky to tell time.

South Korean sci-fi

While South Korea has a long history of science fiction literature, comics and cinema, its popularity exploded with the arrival of PCs in the 1990s. ‘Sci-fi clubs’ sprang up on the internet through chatrooms like Hi-Tel and the impact of online authors like Djuna, with fans able to connect and share stories. Contemporary films such as Space Sweepers (2021, Sung-hee Jo), Jung_E (2023, Yeon Sang-ho) and Bong Joon-ho’s Okja (2017) and Snowpiercer (2013) are major hits both at home and internationally.

Sci-fi screen references in Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver

Ayoung Kim has a longstanding fascination with sci-fi. In her extensive notes, she outlines some of the influences on this work. She describes the villain’s outfit as “somewhat like Neo in The Matrix (1999)”, pays homage to Æon Flux (2005) in a struggle between Ernst Mo and En Storm, and notes, “Creatures resembling jellyfish storm the city like the Zergs from (competitive multiplayer game) StarCraft (1998)”.

The doppelganger

In sci-fi, a doppelganger is a character’s double, often a clone or parallel universe counterpart, exploring themes of identity, duality, and psychological conflict. Repetition of self by means of multiverse is one of the many nods to the sci-fi genre in this work.

Possible worlds theory

Possible worlds theory is a philosophical concept used to explore different ways reality might have been. For example, what if dinosaurs still existed? That scenario would be a possible world. Possible worlds theory helps us consider alternate realities that could exist if different choices were made or different events occurred.

Transworld entities

An individual in our world could have counterparts or even the same identity in other possible worlds. These counterparts or identities can have different properties or make different choices, but they are versions of the same entity. Ernst Mo is a transworld entity.

Ernst Mo and En Storm

“Who was it who said entities couldn’t divide?”

Ernst Mo is a driver with the delivery platform Delivery Dancer. She navigates the different points of a futuristic Seoul as she receives constant calls from the Delivery Dancer app’s AI algorithm “Dancemaster”.

When Ernst Mo encounters her double from another world her life changes. In the first chapter of Kim’s speculative narrative, Delivery Dancer’s Sphere, these two beings become entangled with one another. Each time they meet time slows, disrupting Ernst Mo’s delivery duties. En Storm is both an otherworldly mirror of Ernst Mo and an antagonist in the story. When Ernst Mo defeats Enstorm in the first work, she creates a rift in time and space, finally realising that she’s not bound to one world but is a trans-world being.

In Dancer’s Sphere: 0° Receiver, Ernst Mo now has the power to move between worlds or exist in them simultaneously, with En Storm leading Ernst Mo to an awakening across different worlds, where they experience cooperation, hostility, compassion and understanding toward one another.

Delivery Dancer platform and Dancemaster

A powerful delivery platform that Ernst Mo delivers packages for in this fictional version of Seoul. It is powered by Dancemaster, an algorithm that cheerfully directs Ernst Mo but also controls her time and productivity.

Counterpart theory

The counterpart theory suggests that individuals do not exist in multiple worlds but have counterparts in other possible worlds. These counterparts are similar but not identical to the individuals in the actual world. So, in the counterpart theory, there might be a “version” of you in another possible world, but it’s technically a different individual—a counterpart.

Theory of worldbound Individuals

The theory of worldbound individuals asserts that each individual exists in only one possible world. In other words, an individual in our world cannot be the same as an individual in another possible world, even if they are very similar.

World-building

Worldbuilding is the process of creating an imaginary world for books, film, videogames and other forms of media. It’s about constructing a detailed and immersive setting that feels real and believable, providing a backdrop for characters and events.

Timekeepers and Shadow Definer

The Delivery Dancer platform is part of the Timekeepers’ mission to enforce their idea of ‘Universal Time’ across possible worlds. Universal Time replaces the unique calendar systems of a world with the Timekeepers’ to expand their power over time and space.

Their power is also enforced by the Shadow Definer. Travelling between worlds, the Shadow Definer tracks down beings who aren’t achieving their productivity goals – like Ernst Mo. Controlling productivity is another way the Timekeepers rule time.

The Shadow Definer is named after a gnomon, the triangular part of a sundial, which have been used to measure time since 1200 BCE. The Shadow Definer costume is inspired by The Matrix films.

Dancers’ Power

Dancers’ Power is a multiverse resistance movement. In Kim’s speculative Seoul, Dancers’ Power tries to improve the treatment of Delivery Dancer drivers. Its members can travel to other possible worlds where they resist the Timekeepers and work to preserve each world’s unique time and calendar. In DD0° Receiver, they communicate with Ernst Mo through an unauthorised app, “Guest Stars”, which diverts, deceives and disrupts the GPS that powers Delivery Dancer.

“Guest Stars” was inspired by an unofficial app developed by drivers on the Indonesian platform Gojek. It also references an era before GPS when people would use starts to navigate and tell time.

It’s the only time global positioning systems (GPS), which track Ernst Mo and En Storm’s position and productivity, can be disrupted. This astrological event allows the duo to strike against the algorithm as part of a multiverse resistance.

The symmetrical stone structure seen at the beginning of the artwork is the Vrihat Samrat Yantra, an enormous sundial at the Jantar Mantar observatory in Jaipur, India. It represents an older way of keeping time, offering a counterpoint to digital interfaces like the Delivery Dancer app, which cheerfully gives Ernst Mo her delivery routes and directives.

When Ernst Mo and En Storm fall from the cliff, their own app and travel device, ‘Guest Stars’, activates. You can hear chant-like whispers counting time in different calendar systems, including Buddhist, Celtic, Persian, Hebrew, Hijri (Islamic), Shaka Samvat (Hindu), Jawa (Indonesian), Japanese, Lunar (Korean), Taiwanese and Gregorian calendars, as the characters are transported to other possible worlds. Guest Stars’ was inspired by an unofficial app developed by drivers on the Indonesian platform Gojek. It also references an era before GPS when people would use stars to navigate and the sky to tell time.

South Korean sci-fi

While South Korea has a long history of science fiction literature, comics and cinema, its popularity exploded with the arrival of PCs in the 1990s. ‘Sci-fi clubs’ sprang up on the internet through chatrooms like Hi-Tel and the impact of online authors like Djuna, with fans able to connect and share stories. Contemporary films such as Space Sweepers (2021, Sung-hee Jo), Jung_E (2023, Yeon Sang-ho) and Bong Joon-ho’s Okja (2017) and Snowpiercer (2013) are major hits both at home and internationally.

Sci-fi screen references in Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver

Ayoung Kim has a longstanding fascination with sci-fi. In her extensive notes, she outlines some of the influences on this work. She describes the villain’s outfit as “somewhat like Neo in The Matrix (1999)”, pays homage to Æon Flux (2005) in a struggle between Ernst Mo and En Storm, and notes, “Creatures resembling jellyfish storm the city like the Zergs from (competitive multiplayer game) StarCraft (1998)”.

The doppelganger

In sci-fi, a doppelganger is a character’s double, often a clone or parallel universe counterpart, exploring themes of identity, duality, and psychological conflict. Repetition of self by means of multiverse is one of the many nods to the sci-fi genre in this work.

Possible worlds theory

Possible worlds theory is a philosophical concept used to explore different ways reality might have been. For example, what if dinosaurs still existed? That scenario would be a possible world. Possible worlds theory helps us consider alternate realities that could exist if different choices were made or different events occurred.

Transworld entities

An individual in our world could have counterparts or even the same identity in other possible worlds. These counterparts or identities can have different properties or make different choices, but they are versions of the same entity. Ernst Mo is a transworld entity.

Ernst Mo and En Storm

“Who was it who said entities couldn’t divide?”

Ernst Mo is a driver with the delivery platform Delivery Dancer. She navigates the different points of a futuristic Seoul as she receives constant calls from the Delivery Dancer app’s AI algorithm “Dancemaster”.

When Ernst Mo encounters her double from another world her life changes. In the first chapter of Kim’s speculative narrative, Delivery Dancer’s Sphere, these two beings become entangled with one another. Each time they meet time slows, disrupting Ernst Mo’s delivery duties. En Storm is both an otherworldly mirror of Ernst Mo and an antagonist in the story. When Ernst Mo defeats Enstorm in the first work, she creates a rift in time and space, finally realising that she’s not bound to one world but is a trans-world being.

In Dancer’s Sphere: 0° Receiver, Ernst Mo now has the power to move between worlds or exist in them simultaneously, with En Storm leading Ernst Mo to an awakening across different worlds, where they experience cooperation, hostility, compassion and understanding toward one another.

Delivery Dancer platform and Dancemaster

A powerful delivery platform that Ernst Mo delivers packages for in this fictional version of Seoul. It is powered by Dancemaster, an algorithm that cheerfully directs Ernst Mo but also controls her time and productivity.

Counterpart theory

The counterpart theory suggests that individuals do not exist in multiple worlds but have counterparts in other possible worlds. These counterparts are similar but not identical to the individuals in the actual world. So, in the counterpart theory, there might be a “version” of you in another possible world, but it’s technically a different individual—a counterpart.

Theory of worldbound Individuals

The theory of worldbound individuals asserts that each individual exists in only one possible world. In other words, an individual in our world cannot be the same as an individual in another possible world, even if they are very similar.

World-building

Worldbuilding is the process of creating an imaginary world for books, film, videogames and other forms of media. It’s about constructing a detailed and immersive setting that feels real and believable, providing a backdrop for characters and events.

Timekeepers and Shadow Definer

The Delivery Dancer platform is part of the Timekeepers’ mission to enforce their idea of ‘Universal Time’ across possible worlds. Universal Time replaces the unique calendar systems of a world with the Timekeepers’ to expand their power over time and space.

Their power is also enforced by the Shadow Definer. Travelling between worlds, the Shadow Definer tracks down beings who aren’t achieving their productivity goals – like Ernst Mo. Controlling productivity is another way the Timekeepers rule time.

The Shadow Definer is named after a gnomon, the triangular part of a sundial, which have been used to measure time since 1200 BCE. The Shadow Definer costume is inspired by The Matrix films.

Dancers’ Power

Dancers’ Power is a multiverse resistance movement. In Kim’s speculative Seoul, Dancers’ Power tries to improve the treatment of Delivery Dancer drivers. Its members can travel to other possible worlds where they resist the Timekeepers and work to preserve each world’s unique time and calendar. In DD0° Receiver, they communicate with Ernst Mo through an unauthorised app, “Guest Stars”, which diverts, deceives and disrupts the GPS that powers Delivery Dancer.

“Guest Stars” was inspired by an unofficial app developed by drivers on the Indonesian platform Gojek. It also references an era before GPS when people would use starts to navigate and tell time.

results.title: Strange Cities
results.credit_line:
Creator: Tatiana Pentes
Original musical score: Serge Ermoll (Sergei Emolaeff) and Alexander Vertinsky
Co-development & Cinematography: Geoffrey James Weary
Producer: Eurydice Aroney
Sound Design: Roi Huberman
Interface Design and Programming: Glenn Remington
results.brief_description: ‘Strange Cities’ is an experimental interactive multimedia work that tells of the survival of the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions by two Russian exiles. It draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg to explore memory, transience and the urban imagination. It is an experimental interactive multimedia work authored for CD-Rom release and exhibition. Through the disclosure of evidence, Sasha dreams, discovers, remembers the exilic identity of her grandparents Xenia and Sergei Ermolaeff (a composer and orchestra leader) in fragments and traces of their music, memories, personal effects and photographs, in their struggle to survive the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions. The inspiration for the work is a tune of the same name - a musical illustration, an imaginary vision of old Shanghai, Chinese metropolis, and International Settlement, conjuring mythic, filmic, musical and personal images of the city port. The ‘Strange cities’ musical score1 written by Alexander Vertinsky, Serge Ermoll and Ira Bloch, was first performed by a jazz orchestra of White Russian emigres in the cabarets of the International Settlement of Shanghai, China in the 1930’s and 40’s. ‘Strange cities’ draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg. Coined capital of the international underworld, the city of Shanghai became a seductively strange locale symbolized in the Western imagination, in reality the city was most often the final port of call for political refugees.
results.description:
‘Strange Cities’ is an experimental interactive multimedia work that tells of the survival of the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions by two Russian exiles. It draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg to explore memory, transience and the urban imagination. It is an experimental interactive multimedia work authored for CD-Rom release and exhibition. Through the disclosure of evidence, Sasha dreams, discovers, remembers the exilic identity of her grandparents Xenia and Sergei Ermolaeff (a composer and orchestra leader) in fragments and traces of their music, memories, personal effects and photographs, in their struggle to survive the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions. The inspiration for the work is a tune of the same name - a musical illustration, an imaginary vision of old Shanghai, Chinese metropolis, and International Settlement, conjuring mythic, filmic, musical and personal images of the city port. The ‘Strange cities’ musical score1 written by Alexander Vertinsky, Serge Ermoll and Ira Bloch, was first performed by a jazz orchestra of White Russian emigres in the cabarets of the International Settlement of Shanghai, China in the 1930’s and 40’s. ‘Strange cities’ draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg. Coined capital of the international underworld, the city of Shanghai became a seductively strange locale symbolized in the Western imagination, in reality the city was most often the final port of call for political refugees.

Artist statement:
Strange Cities (Чужие города, Chuzie Goroda) digital work references Shanghainese sinified jazz music, ‘Yellow Music’ (黃色音樂; huángsè yīnyuè) or Shidaiqu (時代曲) - Chinese popular music of the 1920s to 1940s. The color yellow associated with eroticism was condemned as seductive (咪咪知音) ‘decadent sound’ (mimi zhi yin). “A hybrid form inspired by American jazz: Gershwin meets Chinese folk melodies, Tang dynasty love poems, and the romantic cliché of Tin Pan Alley, were expressed in tunes like 美美我愛你 “Darling I Love You” (Meimei wo ai ni)”, see ‘Listening to the Chinese Jazz Age’, in A.F. Jones, Yellow Music, 2001. This music is experiencing a contemporary renaissance as cultural nostalgia to mined. Read more: https://bit.ly/OverTheRosySea
description_for_label: ‘Strange Cities’ is an experimental interactive multimedia work that tells of the survival of the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions by two Russian exiles. It draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg to explore memory, transience and the urban imagination. It is an experimental interactive multimedia work authored for CD-Rom release and exhibition. Through the disclosure of evidence, Sasha dreams, discovers, remembers the exilic identity of her grandparents Xenia and Sergei Ermolaeff (a composer and orchestra leader) in fragments and traces of their music, memories, personal effects and photographs, in their struggle to survive the Russian and Chinese Communist Revolutions. The inspiration for the work is a tune of the same name - a musical illustration, an imaginary vision of old Shanghai, Chinese metropolis, and International Settlement, conjuring mythic, filmic, musical and personal images of the city port. The ‘Strange cities’ musical score1 written by Alexander Vertinsky, Serge Ermoll and Ira Bloch, was first performed by a jazz orchestra of White Russian emigres in the cabarets of the International Settlement of Shanghai, China in the 1930’s and 40’s. ‘Strange cities’ draws upon the legacy of the Shanghai milieu, the Chinese gangster film, a musical cabaret genre, orientalist erotic literature, intrigue novels, and the films of Josef von Sternberg. Coined capital of the international underworld, the city of Shanghai became a seductively strange locale symbolized in the Western imagination, in reality the city was most often the final port of call for political refugees.

results.title: Orchestra of Rust
results.brief_description: ‘Orchestra of rust’ is an installation based interactive that allows the user to create soundscapes and musical pieces via the medium of an entropic industrial environment. The user can explore a zone of decay within an old factory that contains a selection of obsolete machinery. Operating these machines creates particular sounds and corresponding animated sequences. Complex sound structures can be built up from turning on several machines at once. This provides access to other zones of the factory where remixes of the musical creations exist. Also included is extensive interactive information on the background of the machines and sounds, historical sources and concept rationale/hypothesis.

results.title: The Cute Machine
results.creator_credit: Martine Corompt and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description:
The Cute Machine is an exploration into the morphology of cute characterisation and iconography and its relationship to the biological world, seeking to analyse this ‘Cute ideal’ by correlating it with the Zoological process known as Neoteny

The CD contains two sections that had already been exhibited as installations (Sorry! and Activity Station) but were then adapted to a screen version. The remaining sections elaborate on the themes of cute iconography and its analysis.

The Cute Machine proposes an environment where cute iconography and user friendliness have rampantly accelerated, and reduced computer interface design to the look and sophistication of an infant toy, while also taking the premise, Cute = young to the extreme, where the ‘Cutest’, becomes an abstracted mutation of the original sentiment.

results.title: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington's puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
1. “Paddington in the hot seat”. Paddington has an audience ticket for the Quiz Show “Sage of Britain”. He gets lost in the studio complex and finds himself “on camera” where he is interviewed by Lionel Parr. He disputes the scoring and provides his opinion on proposed changes to British Television. The viewers jam the switchboard and Paddington is announced “Sage of Britain”. - 2. “Paddington’s puzzle”. Paddington makes a jigsaw puzzle as a present for Mr Gruber from a “priceless” old painting discarded by Mr Curry, some plywood and glue. - 3. “Paddington takes a cut”. Paddington reads “Clippings from my Hedgerow” and dreams he is pruning Mr Currys’ shrub into a peacock shape. Disaster strikes when he snips it leg off! However, awakes before discovery by Mr Curry!
results.title_for_label: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington’s puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.

results.title: Planning for Melbourne's future
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson, Cine Service and Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works
results.brief_description: In 1949 the Melbourne Metropolitan Board of Works was asked to formulate a plan that would estimate the future needs of Melbourne. From information gathered through surveys, inspecting every street and alley to determine its use, this was made possible. “Planning for Melbourne’s Future” is photographed and directed by Geoffrey Thompson and is an examination of this plan. It is a rare and honest account of the deficiencies and lack of planning made to prepare Melbourne for an increase in future population growth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Thompson, Cine Service and Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works
